title: So if Tracker's Knife was removed for being mandatory in Pro Play...
body: Does that mean you guys will be removing Banner of Command from the game next patch?

replies.body: Banner's certainly strong, but it's still early to say with 100% confidence it's absolutely mandatory. I understand the hype around the item in the EU games especially was off the charts, but already we've seen games where teams didn't take it. I think on the pro stage it'd be foolish not to have a plan for dealing with it right now, but that's true of most meta driving champs and systems.

My issue is that Tracker's Knife was removed, without providing a viable alternative, under the pretence that games would be less safe and therefore more entertaining. Instead, games have far less action because everyone is playing risk-averse, and the teams that are taking risks are being punished for it.

The Banner of Command + Baron interaction has a direct impact on how passively this week's games have been played out because teams simply refuse to take risks before 20 minutes because they know the second baron spawns the enemy team will leverage any advantage they have to take it, and that the Enemy Top Laner already has Banner in their inventory waiting to be cast on a Baron Cannon Minion.

Not to mention, Banner of Command in terms of raw stats is pretty damn efficient for a Tank and nobody else. So Top Lane's champion pool pretty much immediately stagnated because Jungle and Support don't have the gold income to rush it. So here we are back in 2017 watching Maokai vs. Gho'gath every single game.

Sorry, I didn't mean to suggest that I think Banner of Command is in a sustainable spot.

> Instead, games have far less action because everyone is playing risk-averse, and the teams that are taking risks are being punished for it.

I do think it's really hard to know determine how much of this can be attributed to Banner, Tracker's, meta champs, etc. From my own perspective, early games have felt similar to previous patches, not significantly more action, and not significantly less. If that's the case, then perhaps it speaks to there being too few valuable things to do on the map before Baron spawns.
Agreed. But sometimes it can feel like there's no good reason to fight until Baron's up, and since it doesn't spawn for twenty minutes, that can feel like too much downtime.

I mean, I feel like that's a result of the disparity in reward between kills, towers and baron. Baron's value is so out of line with almost every other objective in the game, it makes perfect sense for it to be a major contest.

I think Bannon minions are just symptomatic of this, in that they are getting max value out of an already extremely valuable objective. I can think of a couple ways to stop that:  

A) Making Rift Herald maybe respawn, or stay spawned later, and pushing Baron to be the late-game closer it is maybe intended to be. Or 
B) you need to nerf some other aspect of its reward or it will be so hotly contested it will warp the rest of play around the 20 min mark like we're seeing. Or
C) make Baron at 20 min statistically difficult to defeat, so that it's a bigger risk to fight it if you know it can be contested, i.e. if you start it and they contest you'll be at a large disadvantage.

If it's meant to help early teams ahead by midgame to close out, then it's as it should be. I think the increased pressure for baron fights is good for the game, as it prevents turtling, and also means that the incentive to get baron is at or close to the right place.

And how can you say that Banner isn't already having a significant effect when, in NA at least, in games that 1 team built Banner and 1 team didn't the team with Banner won 100% of those games?

In fact, if I am recalling correctly, Banner was built in something like 18/20 games between NA and EU this week.

> And how can you say that Banner isn't already having a significant effect when, in NA at least, in games that 1 team built Banner and 1 team didn't the team with Banner won 100% of those games?

I didn't say it isn't having a significant effect. I said it hasn't proven to be mandatory.

Banner is an effect that helps teams secure a win. It would make sense that the winning team would be more likely to have one, because the team that is ahead is more likely to get baron, and banner is better with baron. There isn't reason that didn't exist in 8.3 that exists in 8.4 to pick Banner as a team that can't get Baron.

Even if it is determined banner is an unhealthy item for long term in the game I think its important for players understand how banner has evolved and understand how banner really works. Banner if currently being used for a high chance win win situation for the team that gets baron. If one team gets ahead, or believe they can secure baron by superior objective control or mid game teamfighting, they will get banner. However if a team was planning on it but didnt get a lead, sometimes they will just sit on aegis and build a more teamfight item to boost the odds of actually getting baron. Some teams were able to get baron and break base regardless of banner, and sometimes banner had a meaningful impact on its own in the game. While early regions went banner crazy, eventually players realized the minion dematerializer can just delete banner minions and a really strange game was being played during siege not really seen before. This lead to things like back and forth barons or multiple barons needed to be obtained for teams because either their strat got countered, their strat was too narrowminded, or they were playing a relatively similar game to what was happening before. This shows adaptation and brings to question the true impact of banner. At the end of the day, banner isn't an effective strategy in most elos because it requires coordination, one of the strongest power swings in the game, and the ability to execute the push with it. What is way more important is if it is decided as a low interaction, unhealthy, and unfun strategy and way to play league of legends at the top side, and if that is the case is the item need of adjustments, rework, removal etc. I hope people appreciate how much effort is put into understanding and comprehending the change and I wish the best for the balance team! <3 Love these posts keep it up!

So if they execute the full chain, and get BoC + a Baron push or two, it makes sense that they would win.

There is one reason to upgrade the support ap item.  You are an AP support and you want to start wave clearing.

And they specificly wanted to get rid of Ruby Sightstone's item CDR.  It was actually unhealthy when applied in combination with the Ingenious Hunter rune, and they need to rethink (and balance) item CDR before reintroducing it as something you can stack up.

actually, they removed it so that there would not be a choice in the upgraded versions of support items.
formerly, you could choose to have sightstone, or not have it--getting some other active ability if you went without. You could even go the Ruby Sightstone route, and get active item CDR. **The change took these choices away**, and the fact that our current option is more gold efficient is mostly a byproduct.
That is not to say I think the change was a terrible one--I just want you to recognize the cost for what it is.

Cosmic Insight had it before, and not significantly much.  Ingenious Hunter has a more valuable level of it, but item CDR is at the strongest when you stacked up to the max because it stacked additively.  You could get 61% item CDR stacking all the item CDR sources, and it actually was insanely overpowered if you could use it well.  AP support?  Constant barrage of spooky ghost for catches and just safe map travel.  Enchanter support?  Could use Redemption as a casual tool, not a major ult level CD, and may as well just call the Talisman active Sona's E.   Because it had nearly the same value with its lower than 20 second cooldown.   Tank?  Get that Righteous Glory down to a 35 second CD.  Because you really need to have that level of initiation on Alistar every 35 seconds where you can just RG up to them, Q them with the RG slow, then get behind them and kick em back into the team.  Let alone the triple ZZ'rot cheese where you could get 3 of them out at once, or drop a banner 2 times over the span of 2.5 minion waves spawning to really make a wave slowpush in your favor.


If you were running double item CDR runes, Ruby was worth an effective +33% more CDR, not 20%, because of how insane CDR starts to scale once you get over certain values (Every point of further CDR being worth more than the last on an exponential curve.  For example, the value of CDR from 0-10% CDR is less than 2/3rds of the value of the CDR going from 30-40%).
